results.title: The Evil dead (D)
results.creator_credit: Sam Raimi, Robert Tapert and Renaissance
results.brief_description: The Evil dead emerges as the ultimate in low-budget gore and shock effects. Story premise has five youngsters holed up in a remote cabin where they discover a Book of the Dead. An archaeologists tape recording reveals it having been found among the Khandarian ruins of a Sumerian civilization. Playing the taped incantations unwittingly summons up dormant demons living in the nearby forest, which possesses the youngsters in succession until there is only Ash (Bruce Campbell) left to fight for his survival. While injecting considerable black humour, neophyte Detroit-based writer-director Sam Raimi maintains suspense and a nightmarish mood in between showy outbursts of special effects gore and graphic violence which are staples of modern horror pictures. Powerful camerawork suggests the lurking presence of the huge-scale demons in the forest. Filmed in 1980 at Tennessee and Michigan locations for under $400,000, this is a grainy blowup from 16mm film.

results.title: The Explorers [Bill Peach]
results.brief_description: This series follows the trails of the men who opened up the great unknown areas of Australia in the nineteenth century, from the Blue Mountains to the great rivers and deserts.

results.title: Across the Great Divide
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Explorers [Bill Peach]”.
Using historical documents and footage as well as dramatised re-enactments, Bill Peach follows the journey of Evans, Oxley and Cunningham as they cross the Great Dividing Range. He describes the reasons behind their travels, why they chose the route they took, and the ensuing changes to Australian society resulting from their discoveries.

results.title: The Ever-changing lowlands
results.creator_credit: Tony Ianzelo, Joseph Koenig and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: For students of Canadian geography, this film shows the characteristics of the Quebec-Ontario region bordering the United States, where most of Canada’s population settled, and where manufacturing and agriculture thrive.

results.title: The Eye hears the ear sees
results.creator_credit: Gavin Millar, Margaret Dale, British Broadcasting Corporation and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Shakespeare said it first, but here Gavin Millar of the BBC employs the phrase as a tribute to the unique filmmaking career of Norman McLaren. Millar talks with McLaren and another National Film Board film animator, Grant Munro, and shows many examples of the development of the McLaren style. It shows examples of his multiple exposure effects. Demonstrates how he makes moving pictures without cameras and sound tracks without instruments. Includes excerpts from his films, Hen hop, Pas de deux, etc. Photography by Robert Humble. (Awards: New York; Montevideo; Philadelphia.)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gavin Millar, Margaret Dale, British Broadcasting Corporation and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: South to North
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Explorers [Bill Peach]”.
Using dramatised re-enactments as well as historical footage and documents, Bill Peach narrates this investigation of the race to cross Australia from South to North. The race was driven by colonial rivalry between New South Wales and Victoria, resulting in John McDougall Stuart eventually emerging through the centre of the North Coast at the Gulf of Carpentaria.

results.title: The Pinnacle of fame
results.creator_credit: Richard Walker and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Explorers [Bill Peach]”.
Dramatised documentary written and presented by Bill Peach recounting the efforts of three white Europeans to explore the Gippsland and Australian Alps regions. In 1840, Polish geologist and explorer, Paul Strzelecki joined forces with James Macarthur who was interested in exploring the region for grazing land. Strzelecki is considered the first white man to climb Australia’s highest mountain and reach the Kosciusko plateau. Another Polish explorer, Dr John Lhotsky, travelled through the region six years earlier collecting botanical specimens for European museum, but his efforts were not supported by the New South Wales government and his discoveries remain uncredited. Scottish settler, Angus McMillan, was exploring the area during the same period as Strzelecki but chose to conceal his discoveries until he could claim the land as his own. After persevering through hunger and hardship, Strzelecki stumbled across the ranges that bear his name before reaching Melbourne. Here he published details about his findings and the first detailed map of the region. McMillan was outraged when he read the news which omitted any reference to his exploration, furthermore, the rivers and lakes that he had discovered had been renamed by Strzelecki. Strzelecki argued that credit should be given to the explorer who shared his findings and benefits with the public. McMillan was eventually given credit for his exploration of the region while Lhotsky’s efforts failed.

results.title: East to west
results.creator_credit: Bill Steller and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Explorers [Bill Peach]”.
Dramatised documentary written and presented by Bill Peach. Edward John Eyre was the first white man to journey across the Nullabour Plain from the east coast to the west coast. He had originally organised and lead an expedition, beginning in Adelaide, that aimed to travel north through Australia’s centre. This attempt was hindered by mirages that prohibited him from finding a break in a series of lakes that would provide access to the north. Defeated by the desert yet determined not to return to Adelaide as a failure, he decided to attempt an east-west crossing that he had previously advised against. Accompanied by his friend John Baxter, his aboriginal guide Wylie, and two indigenous Australians, Eyre veered west. He persevered across the desolate and forbidding landscape, constantly searching for fresh water and shelter from the elements, as he headed for Perth. Unfortunately, Eyre and Wylie were the only two members of the group who eventually reached Perth following a tragic event that claimed the life of Baxter.

results.title: The Estate
results.creator_credit: Toby Conway-Hughes, Caswell Coggins, Mike Carr, Balletboyz, Crossfire and Channel 4
results.brief_description: A short dance piece set in an English housing estate. The choreography is loosely based on the idea of vultures circling a dying animal, feeling their excitement and anticipation as they gather to feed, waiting for the moment to strike.

results.title: More for less
results.creator_credit: Marty Ostrow, Film Australia, Chedd-Angier Productions and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Race to save the planet”.
A series of case studies which show how fossil fuels can either be used more efficiently or replaced altogether by alternative energy sources. The program stresses, however, that unless the alternatives are shown to be economically advantageous, no matter how environmentally desirable renewable energy sources are, they will not replace fossil fuels in the near future. Teacher’s notes accompany the video.
